SUPPLICATION.elements: Persecutor, Humble Petitioner, and a power in authority whose decision is doubtful.

A: Fugitives imploring the powerful for help against their enemies.
Assistance implored for the performance of a pious duty which has been forbidden.
Appeals for refuge in which to die.
B: Hospitality besought by the shipwrecked.
Charity entreated by those cast off by their own people, whom they have disgraced.
Expiation: the seeking of pardon, healing or deliverance.
The surrender of a corpse, or relic, solicited.
C: Supplication of the powerful for those dear to the suppliant.
Supplication to a relative in behalf of another relative.
Supplication to a mother's lover, in her behalf.

DELIVERANCE.elements: an unfortunate, a threatener, a rescuer.

A: Appearance of a rescuer to the condemned.
B: A parent replaced on the throne by his children.
Rescue by friends, or by strangers grateful for benefits or hospitality.

A: The avenging of a slain parent or ancestor.
The avenging of a slain child or descendant.
Vengeance for a child dishonored.
The avenging of a slain wife or husband.
Vengeance for the dishonor, or the attempted dishonoring, of a wife.
Vengeance for a mistress slain.
Vengeance for a slain or injured friend.
Vengeance for a sister seduced.
B: Vengeance for intentional injury or spoilation.
Vengeance for having been dispoiled during absence.
Revenge for an attempted slaying.
Revenge for a false accusation.
Vengeance for violation.
Vengeance for having been robbed of one's own.
Revenge upon a whole sex for a deception by one.
C: Professional pursuit of criminals.

VENGEANCE TAKEN FOR KINDRED UPON KINDRED.elements: Avenging kinsman, guilty kinsman, remembrance of the victim, a relative of both.

A: A father's death avenged upon a mother.
A mother avenged upon a father.
B: A brother's death avenged upon a son.
C: A father's death avenged upon a husband.
D: A husband's death avenged upon a father.

A: Fugitives from justice pursued for brigandage, political offenses, etc.
B: Pursued for a fault of love.
C: A hero struggling against a power.
D: A pseudo-madman struggling against an Iago-like alienist.

A: Defeat suffered.
A fatherland destroyed.
The fall of a species.
A natural catastrophe.
B: A monarch overthrown.
C: Ingratitude suffered.
The suffering of unjust punishment or enmity.
An outrage suffered.
D: Abandonment by a lover or a husband.
Children lost by their parents.

FALLING PREY TO CRUELTY OR MISFORTUNE.elements: an Unfortunate; a Master or a Misfortune.

A: The innocent made the victim of ambitious intrigue.
B: The innocent despoiled by those who should protect.
C: The powerful dispossessed and wretched.
A favorite or an intimate finds himself forgotten.
D: The unfortunate robbed of their hope.

A: A conspiracy chiefly of one individual.
A conspiracy of several.
B: Revolt of one individual, who influences and involves others.
A revolt of many.

DARING ENTERPRISE.elements: A bold leader, an object, an adversary.

A: Preparations for war.
B: War.
Combat.
C: Carrying off a desired person or object.
Recapture of a desired object.
D: Adventurous expeditions.
Adventure undertaken for the purpose of obtaining a beloved woman.

ABDUCTION.elements: The abductor, the abducted, the guardian.

A: Abduction of an unwilling woman.
B: Abduction of a consenting woman.
C: Recapture of the woman without the slaying of the abductor.
The same case, with the slaying of the ravisher.
D: Rescue of a captive friend.
Rescue of a child.
Rescue of a soul in captivity to error.

A: Search for a person who must be found on pain of death.
B: A riddle to be solved on pain of death.
A riddle to be solved on pain of death, in which the riddle is proposed by the coveted woman.
C: Temptations suffered with the object of discovering his name.
Temptations offered with the object of ascertaining the sex.
Tests for the purpose of ascertaining the mental condition.

OBTAINING.elements: A solicitor and an adversary who is refusing, or an arbitrator opposing parties.

A: Efforts to obtain an object by ruse or force.
B: Endeavor by means of persuasive eloquence alone.
C: Eloquence with an arbitrator.

ENMITY OF KINSMEN.elements: A malevolent kinsman, a hated or reciprocally hating kinsman.

A: One sibling hated by several.
Reciprocal hatred between siblings.
Hatred between relatives for reasons of self-interest.
B: Hatred of the child for the parent.
Mutual hatred of parent and child.
Hatred of the parent for the child.
C: Hatred of grandparent for grandchild.
D: Hatred of parent-in-law for son-in-law or daughter-in-law.
Hatred of two brothers-in-law or sisters-in-law.

RIVALRY OF KINSMEN.elements: the preferred kinsman, the rejected kinsman, and the object.

A: Malicious rivalry of a sibling.
Malicious rivalry of two siblings.
Rivalry of two brothers, with adultery on the part of one.
B: Rivalry of parent and child, for an unmarried lover.
Rivalry of parent and child, for a married lover.
Case similar to the two foregoing, but in which the object is already the spouse of the parent.
Rivalry of parent and child.
C: Rivalry of cousins.
D: Rivalry of friends.

MURDEROUS ADULTERY.elements: Two adulterers, betrayed husband or wife.

A: The slaying of a husband by, or for, a paramour.
The slaying of a trusting lover.
B: Slaying of a wife for a paramour, and in self-interest.

A: Kinsman slain in madness.
A lover slain in madness.
Slaying or injuring of a person not hated.
B: Disgrace brought upon oneself through madness.
C: Loss of loved ones brought about by madness.
D: Madness brought on by fear of hereditary insanity.

FATAL IMPRUDENCE.elements: The imprudent, the victim or the object lost.

A: Imprudence the cause of one's own misfortune.
Imprudence the cause of one's own dishonor.
B: Curiosity the cause of one's own misfortune.
Loss of the possession of a loved one, through curiosity.
C: Curiosity the cause of death or misfortune to others.
Imprudence the cause of a relative's death.
Imprudence the cause of a lover's death.
Credulity the cause of kinsman's death.
Credulity the cause of misfortune.

INVOLUNTARY CRIMES OF LOVE.elements: The lover, the loved, and the revealer.

A: Discovery that one has married one's mother.
Discovery that one has had one's sibling as a lover.
B: Discovery that one has married one's sibling.
Discovery that one has married one's sibling, in which the crime has been villainously planned by a third person.
Being upon the point of taking one's sibling, unknowingly, as a lover.
C: Being upon the point of violating, unknowingly, one's own child.
D: Being upon the point of committing an adultery, unknowingly.
Adultery committed unknowingly.

A: Being upon the point of slaying a daughter unknowingly, by command of a divinity or an oracle.
Through political necessity.
Through a rivalry in love.
Through hatred of the lover of the unrecognized daughter.
B: Being upon the point of killing a son unknowingly.
Being upon the point of killing a son unknowingly, strengthened by Machiavellian instigations.
Being upon the point of killing a son unknowingly, intermixed with hatred of kinsmen.
C: Being upon the point of killing one's brother unknowingly in anger.
Being upon the point of killing one's sister unknowingly through professional duty.
D: Slaying of a mother unrecognized.
E: A parent slain unknowingly through Machiavellian advice.
The slaying of a parent unknowingly.
The insulting of a parent unknowingly.
F: A grandparent slain unknowingly, in vengeance and through instigation.
G: Involuntary killing of a loved woman.
Upon the point of killing a lover unrecognized.
Failure to rescue an unrecognized son.

SELF-SACRIFICING FOR AN IDEAL.elements: The hero, the ideal, the creditor or the person or things sacrificed.

A: Sacrifice of life for the sake of one's word.
Life sacrificed for the success of one's people.
Life sacrificed for the happiness of one's people.
Life sacrificed in filial piety.
Life sacrificed for the sake of one's faith.
B: Both love and life sacrificed for the sake of one's faith.
Both love and life sacrificed for the sake of a cause.
Love sacrificed to interests of state.
C: Sacrifice of well-being to duty.
D: The ideal of honor sacrificed to the ideal of faith.

SELF-SACRIFICE FOR KINDRED.elements: The hero, the kinsman, the creditor or the person or thing sacrificed.

A: Life sacrificed for that of a relative or loved one.
Life sacrificed for the happiness of a relative or loved one.
B: Ambition sacrificed for the happiness of a parent.
Ambition sacrificed for the life of a parent.
C: Love sacrificed for the sake of a parent's life.
Love sacrificed for the happiness of one's child.
Love sacrificed for the happiness of a loved one.
Love sacrificed for the happiness of one's child, but caused by unjust laws.
D: Life and honor sacrificed for the life of a parent or loved one.
Modesty sacrificed for the life of a relative or a loved one.

ALL SACRIFICED FOR A PASSION.elements: The lover, the object of the fatal passion, and the person or thing sacrificed.

A: Religious vows of chastity broken for passion.
A vow of purity broken.
Respect for a priest destroyed.
A future ruined by passion.
Power ruined by a passion.
Ruin of mind, health, and life.
Passion gratified at the price of life.
Ruin of fortunes, lives, and honor.
B: Temptations (see 12) destroying the sense of duty, pity, etc.
C: Destruction of honor, fortune, and life by erotic vice.
The same effect produced by any other vice.

NECESSITY OF SACRIFICING LOVED ONES.elements: The hero, the beloved victim, and the necessity for the sacrifice.

A: Necessity for sacrificing a daughter in the public interest.
Duty of sacrificing a daughter in fulfillment of a vow to God.
Duty of sacrificing benefactors or loved ones to one's faith.
B: Duty of sacrificing one's child, unknown to others, under the pressure of necessity.
Duty of sacrificing, unknown to others, under the pressure of necessity, one's parent.
Duty of sacrificing, unknown to others, under the pressure of necessity, one's spouse.
Duty of sacrificing a son-in-law for the public good.
Duty of sacrificing a son-in-law for the sake of reputation.
Duty of contending with a brother-in-law for the public good.
Duty of contending with a friend.

RIVALRY OF SUPERIOR AND INFERIOR.elements: The superior rival, the inferior rival, and the object.

A: Rivalry of a mortal and immortal.
Rivalry of two divinities of unequal power.
Rivalry of a magician and an ordinary man.
Rivalry of conqueror and conquered.
Rivalry of victor and vanquished.
Rivalry of a master and a banished man.
Rivalry of usurper and subject.
Rivalry of suzerain king and vassal king(s).
Rivalry of a powerful person and upstart.
1Rivalry of rich and poor.
1Rivalry of an honored man and a suspected one.
1Rivalry of two who are almost equal.
1Rivalry of equals, one of whom in the past has been proved guilty of adultery.
1Rivalry of a man who is loved and one who has not the right to love.
1Rivalry of the two (or more) successive husbands of a divorcee.
B: Rivalry of a sorceress and an ordinary woman.
Rivalry of victor and prisoner.
Rivalry of a queen and subject.
Rivalry of a queen and slave.
Rivalry of lady and servant.
Rivalry of a lady and a woman of humbler position.
Rivalry of a lady and two women of humbler class.
Rivalry of two who are almost equals, complicated by the abandonment of one.
Rivalry between the memory or an ideal (that of a superior woman) and a vassal of her own.
C: Double rivalry (A loves B, who loves C, who loves D).
D: Oriental rivalry (Hindu polygamy) of two immortals.
Oriental rivalry (Hindu polygamy) of two mortals.
Oriental rivalry (Hindu polygamy) of two lawful wives.

ADULTERY.elements: A deceived husband or wife and two adulterers.

A: A mistress betrayed for a young woman.
A mistress betrayed for a young wife.
A mistress betrayed for a girl.
B: A wife betrayed for a slave, who does not love in return.
A wife betrayed for debauchery.
A wife betrayed for a married woman.
A wife betrayed with the intention of bigamy.
A wife betrayed for a young girl, who does not love in return.
A wife envied by a young girl who is in love with her husband.
A wife betrayed by a courtesan.
Rivalry between a lawful wife who is antipathetic and a mistress who is congenial.
Rivalry between a generous wife and an impassioned girl.
C: An antagonistic husband sacrificed for a congenial lover.
A husband, believed to be lost, forgotten for a rival.
A commonplace husband sacrificed for a sympathetic lover.
A good husband betrayed for an inferior rival.
A good husband betrayed for a grotesque rival.
A good husband betrayed for an odious rival.
A good husband betrayed for a commonplace rival, by a perverse wife.
A good husband betrayed for a less handsome, but useful rival.
D: Vengeance of a deceived spouse.
Jealousy sacrificed out of pity.
Jealousy sacrificed for the sake of a cause.
E: A spouse persecuted by a rejected rival.

A: A mother in love with her son.
A daughter in love with her father.
Violation of a daughter by her father.
B: A woman enamored of her stepson.
A woman and her stepson enamored of each other.
A woman being the mistress, at the same time, of a father and son, both of whom accept the situation.
C: A man becomes the lover of his sister-in-law.
The man alone becomes enamored of his sister-in-law.
A brother and sister in love with each other.
D: A man enamored of another man, who yields.
A woman enamored of a bull.

DISCOVERY OF THE DISHONOR OF A LOVED ONE.elements: The discoverer and the guilty one.

A: Discovery of a parent's shame.
Discovery of one's child's dishonor.
Discovery of a sibling's shame or dishonor.
B: Discovery of dishonor in the family of one's fiancee.
Discovery that one's wife has been violated before marriage.
Discovery that one's wife has been violated since the marriage.
Discovery that one's spouse previously committed a fault.
Discovery that one's spouse has formerly been a prostitute.
Discovery of dishonor on the part of a lover.
Discovery that one's mistress, formerly a prostitute, has returned to her old life.
Discovery that one's lover is a scoundrel.
Discovery that a so-called king is a scoundrel.
1Discovery that one's spouse is a scoundrel.
1The discovery that one's lover is specifically weakened.
C: Discovery that one's child is an assassin.
D: Duty of punishing one's child who is a traitor to country.
Duty of punishing one's sibling who is a traitor to his party.
Duty of punishing a child condemned under a law which the parent has made.
Duty of punishing one's child believed to be guilty.
Duty of sacrificing, to fulfill a vow of tyrannicide, a father until then unknown.
Duty of punishing a sibling who is an assassin.
Duty of punishing one's mother to avenge one's father.

A: Marriage prevented by inequality of rank.
Inequality of fortune an impediment to marriage.
B: Marriage prevented by enemies and contingent obstacles.
C: Marriage forbidden on account of one partner's previous betrothal to another.
Marriage forbidden on account of one partner's imaginary marriage to another.
D: A free union impeded by the opposition of relatives.
Family affection disturbed by the parents-in-law.
E: Free union impeded by the incompatibility of temper of the lovers.

AN ENEMY LOVED.elements: The beloved enemy, the lover, and the hater.

A: The lover pursued by the brothers of his beloved.
The lover hated by the family of his beloved.
The lover is the child of a man hated by the kinsmen of his beloved.
The beloved is an enemy of the party of the woman who loves him.
B: The lover is the slayer of the father of his beloved.
The beloved is the slayer of the father of the beloved.
The beloved is the slayer of the brother of her lover.
The beloved is the slayer of the husband of the woman who loves him, but who has previously sworn to avenge that husband.
The beloved is the slayer of the lover of the woman who loves him, but who has previously sworn to avenge that husband.
The beloved is the slayer of a kinsman of the woman who loves him.
The beloved is the daughter of the slayer of her lover's father.

AMBITION.elements: An ambitious person, a thing coveted, and an adversary.

A: Ambition watched and guarded against by a kinsman or patriot friend or by a brother.
Ambition watched and guarded against by a relative or person under obligation.
Ambition watched and guarded against by partisans.
B: Rebellious ambition (akin to #REVOLT).
C: Ambition and covetousness heaping crime upon crime.
Parricidal ambition.

A: Struggle against a deity.
Strife with the believers in a god.
B: Controversy with a deity.
Punishment for contempt of a god.
Punishment for pride before a god.
Presumptuous rivalry with a god.
Imprudent rivalry with a deity.

MISTAKEN JEALOUSY.elements: The jealous one, the object of whose possession he is jealous, the supposed accomplice, and the cause or the author of the mistake.

A: The mistake originates in the suspicious mind of the jealous one.
Mistaken jealousy aroused by a fatal chance.
Mistaken jealousy of a love which is purely platonic.
Baseless jealousy aroused by malicious rumors.
B: Jealousy suggested by a traitor who is moved by hatred.
Jealousy suggested by a traitor who is moved by self-interest.
Jealousy suggested by a traitor who is moved by jealousy and self-interest.
C: Reciprocal jealousy suggested to husband and wife by a rival.
Jealousy suggested to the husband by a dismissed suitor.
Jealousy suggested to the husband by a woman who is in love with him.
Jealousy suggested to the wife by a scorned rival.
Jealousy suggested to a happy lover by the deceived husband.

ERRONEOUS JUDGEMENT.elements: The mistaken one, the victim of the mistake, the cause or author of the mistake, and the guilty person.

A: Suspicion where faith is necessary.
False suspicion.
False suspicion (in which the jealousy is not without reason) of a mistress.
False suspicions aroused by the a misunderstood attitude of a loved one.
False suspicions aroused by indifference.
B: False suspicions drawn upon oneself to save a friend.
False suspicions fall upon the innocent.
False suspicions fall upon the innocent spouse of the guilty one.
False suspicions fall upon an innocent but guilty-intentioned.
False suspicions fall upon an innocent who believes themselves guilty.
A witness to a crime, in the interests of loved one, lets accusation fall upon the innocent.
C: The accusation is allowed to fall upon an enemy.
The error is provoked by the enemy.
The mistake is directed against the victim by her brother.
D: False suspicion thrown by the real culprit upon one of his enemies.
False suspicion thrown by the real culprit upon the second victim against which he has plotted from the beginning.
False suspicion thrown upon a rival.
False suspicion thrown upon an innocent because he has refused to be an accomplice.
False suspicion thrown by a deserted mistress upon a lover who left her because he would not deceive her husband.
Struggle to rehabilitate oneself and to avenge a judicial error purposely caused.

REMORSE.elements: The culprit, the victim or the sin, and the interrogator.

A: Remorse for an unknown crime.
Remorse for a parricide.
Remorse for an assassination.
Remorse for a judicial murder.
Remorse for the murder of husband or wife.
B: Remorse for a fault of love.
Remorse for an adultery.

RECOVERY OF A LOST ONE.elements: The seeker and the one found.

A: Recovery of a lost one.

LOSS OF LOVED ONES.elements: A kinsman slain, a kinsman spectator, and an executioner.

A: Witnessing the slaying of kinsmen while powerless to prevent it.
Helping to bring misfortune upon one's people through professional secrecy.
B: Divining the death of a loved one.

A: Thinking someone is rich when he's poor.
B: The wrong man caught in the web of fear.
C: Schizophrenia.
